title: Will the expanded Panama Canal open to shipping before 15 May 2016?
preds:
No news of changes in the plan that the Panama Canal expansion opening will be delayed until possibly June 26, 2016. 
Only 1 week left!

China COSCO Shipping has won the draw for the first transit through the expanded Panama Canal during the waterway's inauguration on 26 June. The company's container vessel Andronikos will make the inaugural transit. The vessel, which has a maximum capacity of 9,400 TEUs, is 8.25m in beam and 299.98m in length.
http://www.sandandgravel.com/news/article.asp?v1=22866
________
This news should do for a 0%

The Panama Canal Authority announced in March that the canal would be inaugurated on June 26th. That's the latest update that I know of, and if that's the deadline they've set for themselves, I expect they'll keep it closed for work and testing right up until that day.

No news of changes in the plan that the Panama Canal expansion opening will be delayed until possibly June 26, 2016.
Only 2 weeks left!
This is probably not going to happen that quickly. There is a lot of work to do still.
No news of changes in the plan that the Panama Canal expansion opening will be delayed until possibly June 26, 2016.

I believe that the Panama Canal will open to shipping before May 16th of this year because it's opening has already been put off carious times. I think that it is reasonable since there is so much work that is going into, for example it will increase the number of ships that flow through the canal as well as increasing the size of ships. Also recent updates show that the completion of the canal project is over 95% complete, this makes it highly likely for it to be operating by next month.

I believe that the Panama Canal will reopen to shipping before May 15. I believe this because the on-going project is already 93% complete, and the rest of the work that is needed is to finish up is only in the lock system. Once they complete the lock system they will be able open the canal to boat traffic, while continuing to finish up other technical details of the canal.
"The Panama Canal Authority (ACP) announced today (3/23) that the Panama Canal Expansion will be officially inaugurated on Sunday, June 26, 2016."
No news of changes in the plan that the Panama Canal expansion opening will be delayed until possibly June 26, 2016.
95% construction projects are delayed, unless survival of human civilization is at play, we would rather play with cell apps such as feeding a turd and taking care of it like a kid
No news of changes in the plan that the Panama Canal expansion opening will be delayed until possibly June 26, 2016.
It is expected to be inaugurated on june 26th.
"A video released by the Panama Canal via YouTube shows the April update for the Panama Canal expansion, which is currently 97% complete and due to be inaugurated on June 26, 2016."
No news of changes in the plan that the Panama Canal expansion opening will be delayed until possibly June 26, 2016.
No news of changes in the plan that the Panama Canal expansion opening will be delayed until possibly June 26, 2016.
No news of changes in the plan that the Panama Canal expansion opening will be delayed until possibly June 26, 2016.
No news of changes in the plan that the Panama Canal expansion opening will be delayed until possibly June 26, 2016.

I'm staying low because I was pretty high early on... but it MAY actually open for shipping before 15 May...
"The Panama Canal Authority is shooting to open its third set of larger locks that can handle post-Panamax ships in May, but it doesnâ€™t expect the larger locks to attract new services for several months."
http://www.joc.com/port-news/panama-canal-news/panama%E2%80%99s-new-locks-seen-slowly-gaining-new-container-services_20160125.html
Ugh... never again will I answer another Canal questions
Report from Reuters saying it will be done in June.
The Panama Canal expansion's planned opening will be delayed until possibly June 26, 2016.
Canal workers now have a goal of May 31st according to this article. http://gcaptain.com/panama-canal-expansion-to-open-end-june/
The Panama Canal expansion's planned opening will be delayed into the second half of June 2016.
we were just there, they've tested it, but expect October 2016 for the grand opening.

official open date announced to be June 26:
http://www.joc.com/port-news/panama-canal-news/panama-canal-locks-officially-open-june-26_20160324.html
CCTV reported that the Panama Canal expansion's planned opening will be in June 2016.
Forecast remains the same, just sharing this link:
Still no news of an early canal opening, and time is running out!

Echoing Tetbury below, there's still no date set, though an announcement is apparently believed to be coming soon:(http://news.co.cr/solid-growth-expected-for-panamas-economy-after-canal-expansion/45757/).
Testing the lock gates will not start until mid-April and the schedule is that at least 2 months will then be required before commercial operation. So that makes the earliest opening date mid-June.

Current (3.17) target for opening the locks to shipping have moved to the end of June.  Although testing of the locks appears to have begun, with completion scheduled for approximately 3.20, it appears unlikely that the schedule will be accelerated.  While it is in theory possible that the locks will open to commercial prior to the 'official' opening, I judge this possibility unlikely given that testing remains (with the possibility that testing uncovers problems that must be resolved before opening).

Although this question isn't closed, it seems almost certainly answered.  I've never heard of a massive construction project being completed weeks ahead of schedule, and they just announced a target date of late June to open the canal:  https://www.yahoo.com/news/panama-aims-end-june-much-delayed-canal-expansion-001713762.html
This trade article states that the new locks have to undergo actual vessel testing in April and that even a late Summer opening to commercial traffic may be overly optimistic.
Still no news of an early canal opening, and time is running out!
testing and trials not expected to be complete until after the 15th
A mentioned b other navigation trials will only be complete by end of May
Navigation trials are expected at the end of May. This one is done. http://www.seatrade-maritime.com/news/americas/trial-phase-begins-on-new-panama-canal-locks.html
This article quotes a spokesperson for the Panama Canal Authority suggesting a completion date of 31st of May if all goes well:
It doesn't look like it will be far off, but expectations are being set for the end of June.
Still no news of an early canal opening, and time is running out!
The contractor and the government have now announced a delay to June: http://gcaptain.com/panama-canal-expansion-completion-delayed-to-end-june/

The Canal Project Minister announced that the Canal expansion would be operational by April 1st, 2016. Yet it is important to consider that this construction project has not exactly been timely—in July 2012 it was announced that the expansion project had fallen six months behind schedule and was to open in April 2015 (the original scheduled opening date was October 2014).  By the time September 2014 rolled around, the canal was expected to opened, and I quote, “at the beginning of 2016.” Clearly the canal is not yet ready and we are well past the “beginning” of 2016. The President of Panama said that he anticipated the expansion of the canal to be complete around May. Therefore by observing past trends of consistent overconfidence of how long the project will take, we can safely assume that the Panama Cana will not be open to shipping before May.

Schedule for the next few months has been announced, with the opening being planned for the second half of the year. http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/news/2016/03/01/panama-canal-expansion-enters-trial-phase/

The Panama Canal's operator has publicly stated that the canal will open by the end of June, following multiyear delays. It is unlikely that it will open in the month preceding his prediction, as after already being delayed from its April opening the operator would have incentive to forecast the opening as soon as possible. H- public statements from those involved in the operation of the project, K- power players in the Panama Canal Expansion project.

from 85 to 10
passage of time, 
no information that support my optimism (but, how can possibly nothing can progress in 3 months???... )
the consensus of my fellow of GJO (who i my to think that my judgment is better??? :-)    )
Further delays announced, so next planned opening is after July 2016?
There will be at least a month's delay. 2 months delay is also quite probable, with 3 months not out of the question.

Rule of government and especially multi national efforts - they come in dramatically over budget and always take longer to complete.  "May" is likely to extend beyond now that the April deadline has been shot down.
Following the wise words of many other forecasters. A more interesting question would be when will the Berlin airport be operational?
The canal's expansion was 96% COMPLETE at the beginning of December 2015.

Reuters reports: "After more than a year-long delay, a new set of larger locks for the Panama Canal will be complete by the end of June, the waterway's administrator said on Wednesday, after builders repaired cracks that had formed in the concrete walls."
end of June at the earliest

No.  But watch the bouncing ball.
Yesterday, I found a report which said it would open at the end of June
Today, it's a different story, unless you read a different article (which says "end of June").
So much for all the politicians pressure to get this done by June.
The Panama Canal's administrator reports that the locks will be opened by the end of June 2016 at the earliest:
Opening has already been delayed, more delays likely.

Perhaps this will be useful in Panama: http://news.mit.edu/2016/cement-structure-solved-0208
(no forecast change)
Its ggoing to be close in meeting the timeline.  opening may occur but have some limitaions on the amount of traffic in can handle.
huge complicated project.  years late , poorly managed.
Recent news indicate another delay after May 1, but before July 1 (optimistic) in an already delayed project.

I'm with @dowser ... I hate canal questions. But this throws it back into the possible pile I think...
http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/money/2016/02/06/repairs-completed-on-cracks-in-new-panama-canal-locks/
it won't be "beyond the 2nd quarter"... which is June. so I see it as a 50-50 chance it could happen before May 15. At least today.
that source from http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/120096 indicates that goverment delayed it. I don't think that government would be ever too pesimistic in announcement of something positive.

Still positive...and the only one to be!
«The filling of the Pacific-facing Cocoli Locks has already begun, and the filling of the Atlantic-facing Agua Clara Locks began today.»
http://www.marinelink.com/news/reinforcements-complete404706.aspx
Recent announcements push this to June at the earliest.
Zika issue touches Panama, and tight capital markets remain an issue.

Panama is led by corrupt politicians who are able to extract more graph from the delays and lack of opening the canal than they will get from keeping the program on schedule.   In India there are programmers.  These guys are smart enough to know that when a development is complete, they lose their jobs.  So projects are never finished, seldom at a point of workable by the launch date.  In India, they pretend to build software, in Panama, they pretend to dig canals.

Panama Canal expansion to be complete by end of June.
http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSKCN0VD07T
It will open in the second half of 2016, not before September.
Failed lockgates test and cashflow problems.

The Panamanian President recently pushed the opening from April to May 2016.  Overall completion of lengthy and complex project is close at @ 97-98%, however, there will likely be other unanticipated problems that further delay opening past May 15th, 2016, although it may be close.
Indications are that the expanded Panama Canal will open to shipping only in the second semester.
"the Panama Canal’s third set of locks will be inaugurated in June – barring any further delays."

28-Jan-2016: “For the expanded canal to be built for the long haul, the focus must remain on quality and testing. This will ensure that the canal continues to provide safe and reliable service for the next century and beyond" says the administrator of the waterway, Jorge Quijano.

"I expect the Panama Canal Expansion to be inaugurated by H2, 2016, with the commercial opening to follow shortly thereafter."
https://www.porttechnology.org/news/panama_canal_chief_releases_expansion_statement
Dropping down five as I have found no indication it will open anytime soon.
Going down 5%. Still don't trust what will happen when there is an "inauguration ceremony" but I've been high for too long.
I am still stuck on the number.
Announcing second quarter would  more likely mean end of quarter at best. Not May
NOT by May.Again the end of 2016.

Recent news from the Canal authority sounds a bit less optimistic, but still predicts opening in "the second quarter" of this year. http://www.joc.com/port-news/panama-canal-news/panama-locks-opening-now-expected-second-half_20160118.html

Commercial shipping _after_ inauguration.
https://www.ajot.com/news/a-note-from-the-panama-cana-authority-administrator
"GUPCâ€™s reinforcement of the lock-sills will be completed this month. Subsequently, the ACP will initiate acceptance tests on the locks and associated elements to ensure quality. This will be followed by vessel trials and training transits through the new Atlantic locks. I expect the Panama Canal Expansion to be inaugurated by the second quarter of 2016, with the commercial opening to follow shortly thereafter.
...
Jorge L. Quijano,
Panama Canal Authority Administrator and CEO"

Cargo Ship Sinks after Collision in Panama Canal
http://worldmaritimenews.com/archives/181481/cargo-ship-sinks-after-collision-in-panama-canal/
There are still many issues not being addressed.

https://www.ajot.com/blogs/full/panama-canal-administrator-says-inauguration-on-schedule-for-june
"In an exclusive interview with the American Journal of Transportation, Panama Canal Authority Administrator Jorge L. Quijano said today [Jan. 21] that the opening to traffic of the expanded canal will not be as late as “early the second part of this year,” as stated Jan. 18 by Francisco Miguez, the authority’s executive vice president of finance and administration of the Panama Canal Authority, at the SMC3 Jump Start 2016 conference in Atlanta and reported by AJOT.
Are you joking - when has a mega project ever been completed on time

There are few problems with Panama canal expansion: 
1. worker strikes
2. disagreements with the consortium responsible for building
3. repairs on the new lock on the Pacific side
4. project size
That link does NOT say second half of year....or it doesn't anymore. It says SECOND QUARTER.....which starts in April. However, I still think unlikely by May 15th.

Panama locks opening now expected in second half of year
http://www.joc.com/port-news/panama-canal-news/panama-locks-opening-now-expected-second-half_20160118.html
Updated news stating "Second Half of the Year"

As with all projects, this is long overdue. The current hoped for opening is May - but there's still time for problems to occur to cause more delays. The commitment to open in May will be satisfied even if they only do so on 31 May. So there is no incentive for them to get it done by 15.

“We expect it to be open for commercial business sometime in the second half of the year,” said Francisco J. Miguez, executive vice president for finance and administration at the Panama Canal Authority, in a speech at the SMC3 JumpStart 2016 supply-chain conference in Atlanta.
Now that an official announcement predicts "second half of the year", I'm only putting token probability on anything else.
Want to be below consensus and in these cases delays beget delays - balance of risks has to be to the downside of an open date
Down 10% on @einsteinjs (I'm also guessing that the Inauguration Day celebration will also be delayed.)
I was overly optimistic on this. I thought it would be close, but betting that it would open on time. Sounding like it will not open until at least 3Q.
Up 10% after I considered what I responded to @Khalid

Saying the project will open in April, and then 2 days later saying an April date would be impossible indicates that the project is further behind than they want to admit.  The person who stated that May would be the deadline is incentivized to give a best-case, and not a realistic answer.  My guess is that the May date is feasible if everything goes perfectly; which with construction rarely happens.

I'm confident it won't be "open to shipping" before 15 May. None of the players involved are now committing to this, even the contractor who says it's technically feasible but practically impossible. There could be an "Inauguration", though, but (I hope!) simple ribbon-cutting shouldn't resolve this IFP.
The new locks are leaky.  It was scheduled to open in 2014, then delayed to April 2015.  It will probably be delayed again

Many web sites (presumably same source) report that invitations to the opening were sent out in October or November to 70 heads of state. They don't say the date of the inauguration. Some are assuming April. Perhaps they are right; invitations sent 6 months in advance. It is looking like the Canal will not open for shipping on the inauguration date, which seems embarrassing. But I'm sure you have to get those invitations out early, as heads of state do not make last-minute changes in plans in order to attend a party. I'm still thinking it won't open in May, but I'm not seeing any updates about the repairs that were supposed to be completed this month.

Just came across an article in the Journal of Commerce dated Dec. 28, 2015 which says "Conflicting, adversarial and ambiguous messages from the Panama Canal Authority, or ACP, and Grupo Unidos Por el Canal, the consortium building the expansion’s new locks, have cast doubt over whether commercial operations will debut by mid-2016 at all.  The canal authority has not disclosed when a it now expects to inaugurate the project. The earliest would be some time in the second quarter of 2016, officials have said. Officials with GUPC have been even less clear, saying “April 2016 remains feasible as a functional completion date” then saying an April commercial opening is nothing short of “impossible” just two days later." See http://www.joc.com/port-news/panama-canal-news/panama-canal-expansion-now-96-percent-complete_20151228.html

(no change) All great points for why it won't happen. I'm at 5% because I can't help but wonder if there will be a "Parchin moment" when something (rowboat transiting, etc.) and a celebration and it is "open."

I am not sure if this is a mistake, or a typo, or what, but the Panamanian Archbishop said: "we are confident that [it] will be delivered during the second half of this year." Most other commentators have stated the second quarter.
http://www.latinone.com/articles/30725/20160115/panama-canal-authority-meets-archbishop-discuss-expansion.htm
Sacyr (the leader corporation) is in conflict with ACP (Authority for Panama Channel). Their finantial situation is limit. They are asking more money because overcosts.
nothing ever gets done on time

Hapag-Lloyd won’t upsize Panama Canal tonnage before year's end
http://www.joc.com/maritime-news/container-lines/hapag-lloyd/hapag-won%E2%80%99t-upsize-panama-canal-tonnage-end-year-ceo-says_20160114.html

The long-delayed expansion of the Panama Canal is now expected to be finished by May, instead of April as was previously announced, Panamanian President Juan Carlos Varela said Saturday. Varela made the announcement in an address to the Central American country. However, they have continuously moved the date up, so I think there is only a fair chance that President Varela can make good on his promise.

Based on the current leaks, repair schedule, and test schedule and target of 2Q16 from the developer, and based on my experience with large-scale integration projects, it's likely that the contractors will use every bit of their target timeframe to open the Canal. For instance, the original schedule called for 3 months of testing the canal before opening. Those tests are not currently scheduled to begin until April, putting the canal opening into late June or early July. The pressure to open in May as announced by President Varela may pressure the contractors to reduce the test schedule, regardless, their likely to use all of May to have the best chance of opening the canal successfully.
Although some predict it will open in April/May, there have already been high costs and numerous delays due to leakages. High costs combined with corruption indicate a likely delayed opening.

There has been debate about this but although there have been some leakages, some sites suggest the canal may open in April/May. However, because of high costs and large delays that have already happened, and the fact that most projects or projected dates like this are too ambitious, there is not enough evidence to support that the canal will really make the May 2016 date and be ready for shipping by this date.

I read a number of stories on the canal expansion and most indicate that the canal will open in April despite setbacks from leakage at one of the locks. There should be an update within a week or two and I will revise up or down depending on the report.
Legal case is a side show. If lock door fix works, commercial opening will follow shortly after ceremonies.
No point in losing one percentage point. Going down to 0%.

Internal squabbles over costs have plagued the expansion project for several years.  In February of 2014, a dispute between GUPC and The Panama Canal Authority (ACP) over who should pay for what was then $1.6 billion in cost overruns led to work being halted on the project.
With delays the norm, forecasting a less than one month delay past the scheduled April open date seems very unlikely.

Given the multiple delays with the expansion project, it seems unlikely the expanded Panama Canal will be open to shipping before 15 May 2016.  There have been numerous cost overages and the project was initially supposed to be finished sometime in 2014 - only to have the deadline pushed back to April 2016.
With the completion officially slated for "around May" and the criminal complaint against the contractors it seems unlikely that the expanded canal would be certified for shipping by 15/5/16.

Reports are circulating in Panama that Grupo Unidos por el Canal (GUPC) overseeing the expansion of the Panama Canal is facing an investigation after a criminal complaint was filed against it for inflating cost overrun claims.  The project has a long history of legal claims for fraud slowing or stopping work, my forecast can't go much lower, but I am moving it downwards.

Big projects like this are rarely on-time, especially since there is no "one off" event they must hit. If they rush, it would be huge disaster. And hey, it's Latin America, so nothing is ever precisely on time.
One more down revision (same reasoning as previous comment)
Revising down my forecast, to take into account
Lawsuits being filed. Never a good sign for speedy construction.
From 3% to 1%. Based on the reasoning in my first nothing else makes much sense.
Reconcile expectations and taking an aggressive view based on some very good comments made by Lord_selfie and others

Criminal Charges Filed Against Panama Canal Expansion Firm
http://news.co.cr/criminal-charges-filed-against-panama-canal-expansion-firm/43894/
The much-anticipated Panama Canal expansion project is now 96 percent complete, but will not be open to commercial traffic in April as previously reported, according to the canal authority.
Going down 10% on all the links regarding schedule options and to be below the consensus for scoring purposes.

I am persuaded by information in the many helpful links posted in the comments section that this is extremely unlikely to happen by 15 May 2016. There is simply too much at stake to get this wrong and, from what I understand, potentially enormous construction problems not yet overcome. There is no national election until 2019 and so no one too embarassed by short, but for our purposes extremely consequential, delays. The head of the Panama Canal Authority, Jorge Quijano, says no later than June. Since that date is now being raised publicly I see it as extremely unlikely for the criteria to be met by mid-May.

Given that recent news indicate that the expansion would be finished in May and then "sea trials" need to take place, which will take at a minimum a few weeks. These technical reasons, coupled with labor and money disputes create a low threshold for shipping on May 15th. The only issue that I can see pushing my 5% forecast upwards would be intense pressure by major users of the canal to resolve the labor and money issues.

"A commercial opening date will follow soon after the inauguration event"
http://www.ttnews.com/articles/basetemplate.aspx?storyid=40464
Repackaged news with a bit more detail.
"The longer you wait, the longer you will be expected to wait" by N. N. Taleb (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lindy_effect)

Even the official word is now "no later than June":
http://container-mag.com/2015/12/24/ballast-water-rules-edge-closer/

Projects of this complexity and  scope often face hurdles to meet schedule. Announced date leaves little leeway  to meet question conditions. Admission of leak repairs reduces likelihood further. One or more weather events in El Nino year add uncertainty

I've read in many sources that the President is now saying the Panama Canal expansion project is tentatively set to be complete 'around the month of May'.  . . .  "tentatively", "around", "the month of"
Recent schedule announcement said inauguration mid-May, commercial shipping begins several weeks later. They could surprise to the positive side, but I'll take them at their word.
Just a bet on the planning fallacy holding true.
Payment schedule not respected, technical and structural problems already appearing, testing phase and surveying work projected to take double time in light of structural deficiencies

Many of the past posts and current links lead me to believe the biggest hurdle to an on-time project completion is related to money not actual construction or testing of the work.  Below is the latest news.  I posted in the past there may not be incentive to open on time secondary to shipping companies losing money and poor shipping outlook near term.  That may not be relevant in this case.  Perhaps President Varela has other incentive to open on time.  I’ll upgrade my forecast based on Varela statements.  15 May deadline will be tough to forecast.
too may unknowns from terror, finance, political instability etc.

Lowering a little more as the news lack enthusiasm for a grand opening
http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/news/2016/01/02/panama-expanded-canal-to-be-inaugurated-in-may/

- The project has a history of delays and issues
 -The contractor is hedging its bets on finishing it in April, blaming preempitvely the Canal Authority 
http://www.gupc.com.pa/en/press/press-releases/252-finalizacion-de-obra
+ They're at 96%. The last 4% should be doable if all goes well. That seems like a big if
Projected opening is now "sometime in month of May".  That gives a very tight 15 day window for this even if you assume not further delays.

President is saying inauguration in May, but most likely open to shipping later...
http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/news/2016/01/02/panama-expanded-canal-to-be-inaugurated-in-may/
Lowering prob. in light of cite by @Anneinak. Sounds like they'll be lucky to begin operations by the end of May.
The projected opening date has slipped at least three times, so a (very) rough Bayesian calculation with nAccurate = 0, nInaccurate = 3 gives
Inauguration expected in May. Seems unlikely that the Canal will be open to shipping before mid-month. If they're saying May, it's probably going to be later.
Projects are always too delayed than we expexf

Varela announced an opening in May...but half the month is after May 15 :)
http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/news/2016/01/02/panama-expanded-canal-to-be-inaugurated-in-may/
Any big project which is due to be completed soon has a high probability of being delayed
has anyone seen any repair work on the damaged sections?

No change in forecast. http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/news/2016/01/02/panama-expanded-canal-to-be-inaugurated-in-may/ notes that even after inauguration (supposedly sometime in May) the canal may not actually open for shipping for some time.
To me at this very moment, it seems very very unlikely that the canal will open for shipping before 15. May.
Big work tend to finish past the deadline

The effect of El Nino has already been felt with a decrease in the maximum draft of panamax ships that can pass through the waterway.  And since the canal was expanded for those larger ships, it's possible the canal won't be fully operational (without draft restrictions) until after el nino ends in late spring/early summer and water levels hopefully normalize.
Now this is a tricky one:
Reducing 40% to bring my forecast more in line with consensus. (still think more like 60-40 pro for something that might trigger a yes)

Reduced to reflect public admission that commercial opening (which I hope is what it takes to fulfill this question) will be delayed past the April opening date, and assuming the delay would be at least two more weeks afterwards.
The economic slow down in emerging markets and global fall in commodities prices may further delay the canal opening for shipping because shipping volume has decreased and may drop further in 2016.

There is little incentive to open the expanded canal before 15 May 2016.  However, “Jorge Quijano head of the Panama Canal is still confident of a second quarter opening and no later than June 2016” [1].  BOYD schedules ships for the Panama Canal on their website a month in advance [1].  An objective assessment for a 15 May 2016 expanded Canal open will have greater predictability by mid April.
The expanded canal will open.  Nevertheless, what will be the catalyst to open before 15 May 2016? Expanded shipping lane demand may not necessarily be forecasted based on worldmaritimenews comments, “Shipping Confidence Continues Downward Trend” [2].  “OOCL Asia-Europe revenue slumps 32.2%” [3]. Additionally, depressed oil prices offer alternative transports more attractive.  A brief look at DOW transports indicates a breakdown in technical patterns on daily, weekly and monthly charts.  Contractual obligations may be one of the few incentives for a 15 May 2016 open.  
Culturally, Panamanians have less emphasis towards timelines, however, I’m not sure how this will influence the completion date of the canal [4].  I might have an improved forecast mañana.
[1] http://www.boydsteamship.com/booking.php
[2] http://worldmaritimenews.com/archives/179152/shipping-confidence-continues-downward-trend/
[3] http://www.lloydslist.com/ll/sector/containers/article471625.ece
[4] http://www.anywherepanama.com/travel-guide/people-and-culture

New Year's Resolution to look afresh at previous predictions:-). I had been optimistic that they would be able to do whatever it takes to declare the Canal "open" on time - even if some minor work remained to be done - but the dispute between the parties and mutual recriminations at this stage sound more like people preparing to blame each other for a missed deadline rather than "tough talk" as part of some negotiation.  We still have 4.5 months to go, but I am shifting negative to 10% and will look for evidence in the upcoming testing of the lock repairs that they might be getting back in track.

Planned opening : April in August 2015
Very height viability and economic value for America to stay on track.
Gigantic project rarely finish on time as planned 6 months before and here there are issues too (http://container-mag.com/2015/08/25/cracks-lock-may-delay-panama-canal-expansion/)
Unlikely it opens on time:
http://container-mag.com/2015/12/24/ballast-water-rules-edge-closer/
Going down 10% on Anneinak's post. Seems like all the news is repackaged (like the Iran S-300) but I still think the criteria are too squishy to not permit a yes even on relatively thin grounds.
(no change for now) Any hard information about contract language (and implications for fines, resolving progress payment issues, etc.)? Would opening matter to Panamanian political classes?

Panama officials anounced las week they plan to start testing in April 2016. After testing, if it all goes well, inaugural ceremony, and then start of comercial operations. It all seems too much considering extreme complexity and long history of delays of this proyect.
Continued official confusion regarding opening in April causes me to continue to heavily lean against a second quarter opening.

Engineers being what they are (deliberate, conservative, and risk-averse to the point of Asberger-ish), there is no amount of pressure that will force a date on the project ahead of its safety-assured due time of completion.

Seems like delay after delay is occurring.  First it's leaks.  Then it's failure to pay contractors.  April has already pretty much been ruled out, that leaves a small 2 week window.  All reports seem to point toward a decelerated schedule.

Based on a recent article ( http://www.joc.com/port-news/panama-canal-news/panama-canal-expansion-now-96-percent-complete_20151228.html ), two critical aspects force me to assess that there is a %0 percent chance of the expanded canal opening to shipping prior to 15 May 2016.
1. Leaky locks - While the two sills of the locks on the Pacific side may be repaired prior to the deadline, the sills/locks still have to be tested via a chartered ship. And there is no guarantee that this test will be successful.
2. Bureaucracy and payment issues: Excerpt from article: "...Then, two days later, in a Spanish news service EFE interview with GUPC chief executive Giuseppe Quarta. Quarta was quoted saying that an April 2016 completion date would be “impossible” given the ACP’s “bureaucratic and payment rhythm”, which if not accelerated would delay completion by another six months."
Up 70% on jeremylichtman's link regarding transit testing.

It is currently estimated that the Canal will open in April (including its accommodation design changes).  Further changes in implementation will cause additional delays moving it closer to the May date ...
Large infra-structure projects are often behind schedule

Initial assessment:
1. 96% completion (according to official website http://micanaldepanama.com/expansion/)
2. Has leak been fixed? Here's a cynical POV on that subject (http://latincorrespondent.com/2015/12/leaking-locks-disrupt-panama-canal-expansion/). Will come back to this issue in mid-January - the estimated date of completion for correcting this problem.
3. How are the financial issues affecting development of this project? Here's an article ascribing to it  http://container-mag.com/2015/12/24/ballast-water-rules-edge-closer/(at the end). ACP claims, based on this, that completion will be no later than June 2016.

Last night's article from IHS Fairplay solidifies my gut feeling that there is a lot of treachery going on below the bureaucratic surface of the canal timeline, suggesting a "rising risk of further delays." Having been involved in some construction projects in Central America, I know that this kind of adversarial posturing is usually politically driven, which reduces the priority of the construction schedule in favor of saving face.

to far behind to make it.

Substantial lock and navigation testing remains to be done, and given the history, more problems might well turn up.  Also putting the opening under pressure is a useful lever to negotiate cost overrun problems.

Repairs to the third set of locks are current slated for completion in January, delaying navigation tests to April.  In addition to the un-scheduled repairs, the prime contractors have publicly voiced complaints regarding payment timelines.  These delays may be due in part to political changes resulting from the 2014 elections if news reports are to be believed.  That said, the project is currently at 96% complete and barring serious faults in the sill repairs to the third lock set it appears plausible for the remaining work to be completed in time for an opening prior to June.
These things run over schedule more often than not
Major projects like this have run over time and budget around the world. This one is even more complex than your typical project -- so no chance that comes in on time.
Current estimate is April 2016.  That said the recent leaks suggest that the cause of delays would put all shipping to a halt, meaning it would not be able to open even in a partial way.
Chances are it will be opened on time, however there are likely to be significant constraints affecting throughput.
Original date was early April, but work on sills will be complete by January 2016, so May 15 seems possible.
Chances of any large engineering project being finished on schedule are very low. The larger the project, the longer the delay.

It is rare that any engineering project of this magnitude finished on schedule, and there is no urgency to complete it anytime soon considering shipping raw materials from Brazil to China, and consumer goods for East Asia to East Coast USA will probably experience little growth in 2016.
Reducing from 7% given issues with the walls.  Continue to believe that there is no economic incentive to get done on time since world trade has all but collapsed.

based on the confirmations that it is delayed further.

Staying at the median until January, when there should be more information after some repair work is completed. If they decide to limit repairs to rebar and epoxy, the Canal might still open before 15 May.

The head of the project just hedged today, saying the opening will not happen in April and refusing to give a date until mid-January when some repair work is complete. Dropped my prediction from 70 to 38. I could see this quickly going to near zero if they announce in January a further delay.

There have been weather and strike related delays, as well as checks on the reinforcement of locks in the canal. The Wall Street Journal reported in October that an April opening is on schedule. Still, the importance and prestige of this project suggest that every effort will be made to achieve the original schedule and the recent apparent confidence with the issue of the locks should enable this.

Reinforcing of sills is projected to finish by January, so it appears that they are determined that the crack issues will not be used as an excuse to push the opening, even though from a quality-point-of-view, they may have been better served to spend the time to fix them right.  I think it's possible that the rush to finish may still be inevitably delayed by a failure of the band-aid approach to the cracks, but that possibility is probably low, given the stakes involved here.

Looks like they're planning to reinforce the locks with steel bars rather than demolish and re-pour the affected locks. This will still put them behind schedule, but perhaps not so much that the canal won't open before May 15. Whatta mess.

There is some serious money involved in going through the Panama Canal. For instance, it costs close $100 per container to go through the locks. With the much bigger container ships using the PanaMax canal, this is close to $400K per ship (with the other fees tacked on). Somehow Panama will find a  way to open as quickly as possible.
I think they are really trying to not miss another deadline, however, the new cracks discovered in August seem to be a bit much.

Finally an answer to my question on how steel reinforcements are supposed to fix seepage. The answer is that they won't. Instead, it's epoxy time: "...and we will inject a resin in the cracks that occurred". http://thebulletinpanama.com/2015/11/cracks-under-repair-in-canal-expansion/

Recently visited Panama. There's a strong political pressure to open the Canal, the inauguration has been delayed already 18 months. In January, the consortium building will determine if it will be ready by April 2016. Work is being done to reinforce five walls and to  repair the one with the cracks.

Weighing in recent debates about impact, my thought at this point is that it could easily slip 45 days due to the additional issues and associated friction along the supply and labor chain to activities that would be hard to time well even under ideal circumstances.  There is enough pressure to do this correctly, given the other ports that will need to expand upstream (figuratively speaking) from this port but aren't ready yet that I think "doing it right" will trump "doing it fast" in terms of final calls from decision-makers.  Not extremizing this yet, but re-rating this to only a 1:3 chance given obstacles.

Panama site with a lot of good info, although the November update is still missing.  Last news post on the site was in September 2015.  In the September post GUPC (Grupo Unidos por el Canal) verbally reported to the ACP (Panama Canal Authority) that April 2016 was stil the completions date.  The ACP is still awaiting GUPC's formal confirmation of the date.
   Reinforcement of the 1st and 2nd Cocoli Locks, and the 1st 3 in the Atlantic facing Agua Clara Locks will be reinforced (as a preventative) as well as the leaking lock.  Further testing, and 1/20 th of the coverall construction is still unfinished.
   ************ The site reports that GUPC is contractually liable for all corrections required to be made to the locks.  Since the contractor is responsible for the long term performance of the locks, it seems unlikely that GUPC would allow the locks to operate in a condition that would further degrade them thereby increasing future risk to the contractor. *********
   Repairs will need to be followed by more testing....unions not 100% cooperative, actually gaining more leverage as the due date approaches.  Requests for outside inspection of the construction is also a risk to the completion date.

I'm giving a higher prediction than the average because I think we need to also consider the proposed Chinese canal in Nicaragua. The sooner the canal is enlarged in Panama, the less likely a rival canal will be set up in Nicaragua. This would be a large geopolitical victory for the U.S. against China, thus why I think it's at least possible that the canal is finished by May 15th, 2016.

Most major construction projects fail to open on time and this one is already flagged up to take about 20-25% longer than originally slated.  When the man in charge says a project will definitely open by a certain date, there is as good as zero chance that it will open earlier than that. Factors against opening in May 2016:
- There have been delays in the past
- Testing can take anywhere from 3 to 7 months depending on sources
- Problems have been already found in the steel doors, and recently samples taken from the massive concrete structure have also shown apparently serious problems
- They've faced financing problems in the past, with construction being paralised in 2014 and Spain and Panama intervening in the conflict; this is still being discussed in international courts, and opening of the Panama Canal could be a leveraging factor for negotiations
no, nothing comes in quickly. public projects are frankensteins. early dates are touted to get bids accepted
